tossups.question: A film from this country, which follows the life of an Italian independence fighter Arthur Burton, is titled The Gadfly. In another film from this country, a sailor ponders the meaning of the phrase “give us this day our daily bread” before smashing a plate. In that movie from this country, a rebellion breaks out after some soldiers are forced to eat (*) maggot-filled meat. Later in that film, an old woman gets shot through her eyeglasses as cavalry indiscriminately shoot civilians at the bottom of the Odessa Steps. For ten points, name this country home to Sergei Eisenstein, the director of Battleship Potemkin.
tossups.answer: Soviet Union [or Union of Soviet Socialist Republics; prompt on Russia]
tossups.answer_formatted: Soviet Union [or Union of Soviet Socialist Republics; prompt on Russia]

tossups.question: This author critiqued W.H. Auden’s use of the term “murder” and praised Henry Miller in “Inside the Whale.” At the end of a short story by this author, the narrator claims that they performed the title action “solely to avoid looking a fool” in front of a Burmese village. At the end of a novella by this author of (*) “Shooting an Elephant,” two characters play an ace of spades at the same time. The title locale of that work by this author is located between Pinchfield and Foxwood. Moses the raven sings the praises of Sugarloaf Mountain in one work by this author that features the pigs Napoleon and Snowball. For ten points, name this author of Animal Farm.
tossups.answer: George Orwell [accept Eric Arthur Blair]

tossups.question: The inability to exactly determine some of these values results from the icosahedral group being non-abelian, a major result of Galois theory. Bairstow’s method generalizes a method for calculating these values in which a function divided by its derivative is subtracted from an initial guess. These values have no general formula for a polynomial of degree five or greater according to the (*) Abel-Ruffini theorem. The number of these values equals the degree of a polynomial by the fundamental theorem of algebra. These values for a two degree polynomial can be determined using the quadratic formula. For ten points, name these values where a function is zero.
tossups.answer: roots of polynomials [or solutions; accept zeroes until it is mentioned]
tossups.answer_formatted: roots of polynomials [or solutions; accept zeroes until it is mentioned]

tossups.question: This holiday traditionally involves distribution of the cannabis-based drink bhang. This holiday is similar to one practiced in more rural religions, called Rangapanchami. On the eve of this holiday, bonfires are lit to celebrate the survival of Prahlada, who was tricked into sitting on a funeral pyre by the sister of King Hiranyakashipu. Many events such as (*) “color runs” have been accused of appropriating aspects of this holiday. This holiday is associated with the coming of spring. For ten points, name this Hindu festival that often involves people throwing colored powder on each other.
tossups.answer: Holi

tossups.question: This ruler established diplomatic relations with the Ottoman Empire with the chartering of the Levant Company. This monarch suppressed the Steelyard, a Hanseatic trading outpost in their country. Spymaster Francis Walsingham uncovered a plot led by Anthony (*) Babington to assassinate this ruler. This ruler names the peak period of the English Renaissance, where artists such as William Shakespeare flourished at the Globe Theatre. This Protestant ruler reversed much of the Catholic reforms of her older half-sister, Mary I. For ten points, name this Tudor ruler known as the “Virgin Queen.”
tossups.answer: Queen Elizabeth I [prompt on Elizabeth]

tossups.question: The final stanza of this poem quotes The Spanish Tragedy by stating “Hieronymo’s mad againe.” The speaker of this poem attempts to convince Lil to buy a pair of false teeth so that Albert does not cheat on her. A “Phoenician Sailor” in this poem who was “once handsome and tall as you” appears on a tarot card shown to the speaker by (*) Madame Sosostris. The phrase “HURRY UP PLEASE IT'S TIME’ is repeated in a section of this poem entitled “A Game of Chess,” and its other sections include “The Fire Sermon” and “What the Thunder Said.” “April is the cruelest month” begins, for ten points, what poem by T.S. Eliot that depicts a barren place?
tossups.answer: “The Waste Land”

tossups.question: In this region, a mosque was sprayed with blue dye twice with a water cannon during a police operation. In response to the Fugitive Offenders amendment, people stormed this region’s Legislative Council Complex. Transparent elections were emphasized by a movement in this city named after an (*) umbrella. Over 210,000 protesters formed a 50 kilometer human chain to draw attention to five demands in this city. In September 2019, pressure from Anti-ELAB protests led the Chief Executive of this city, Carrie Lam, to withdraw an extradition bill. For ten points, name this Chinese special administrative region returned to China by Britain in 1997.
tossups.answer: Hong Kong [or Xianggang]

tossups.question: ANSWER: Hong Kong [or Xianggang] <AY, Current Events>  8. Newspaper editor Carl Magee helped uncover this event by writing about a perpetrator’s sudden payment of ten years of property taxes. John Kendrick’s resolution to look into this event led to Thomas Walsh and Robert La Follette leading a federal investigation into it. The right to compel testimony about this event was affirmed in the court case (*) McGrain v. Daugherty. During this event, land in Elk Hills was leased to Edward Doheny, and property was leased by Secretary of the Interior Albert Fall to Harry Sinclair. For ten points, name this scandal during the Harding administration concerning a Wyoming oil field.
tossups.answer: Teapot Dome Scandal

tossups.question: Analysis of this scientist’s DNA in 1994 revealed that he suffered from deuteranopia rather than protanopia. This scientist names a form of color blindness that results from discoloration of the vitreous humor. This scientist observed that compounds contain whole number ratios of elements. A law named for this scientist states that the total (*) pressure of a mixture is equal to the sum of the partial pressures of the individual components. This scientist proposed the “billiard ball” model of the atom, stating that all atoms of the same element have the same properties and represent an indivisible unit of matter. For ten points, name this English chemist who pioneered atomic theory.
tossups.answer: John Dalton

tossups.question: Johannes Brahms wrote a trio in E-flat major for this instrument, violin, and piano. Richard Strauss’s An Alpine Symphony is unusually scored with twenty of these instruments, including twelve offstage used to represent a hunting party. Strauss also wrote two concertos for this instrument, both of which were written in E-flat major. This instrument, which is made up of two instruments pitched in F and B-flat, can be (*) hand-stopped in its bell to lower the pitch of a note and is used to represent the wolf in Prokofiev’s Peter and the Wolf. For ten points, name this triple-valved brass instrument, typically the most common instrument in an orchestra’s brass section.
tossups.answer: French horn [or double horn in F/B♭; accept German horn; accept F horn before “pitched in F”; do not accept or prompt on “English horn”]
tossups.answer_formatted: French horn [or double horn in F/B♭; accept German horn; accept F horn before “pitched in F”; do not accept or prompt on "“English horn”"]

tossups.question: One of these figures kills a demon by placing him on his thighs and disemboweling him with his fingernails. Another one of these figures appears at the end of each “stage of the world,” or yuga, and draws his flaming sword atop a white horse. Kalki is one of these figures, as is another being who kills Hiranyakashipu in a doorway at twilight and is named Narasimha. One of these figures states (*) “I am become death, destroyer of worlds” in the Bhagavad Gita, where he lectures Arjuna on dharma and serves as his charioteer. For ten points, identify these incarnations of a Hindu preserver god, including Rama and Krishna.
tossups.answer: avatars of Vishnu [accept dashavatara, anti prompt on “Kalki,” “Narasimha” or “Krishna”]
tossups.answer_formatted: avatars of Vishnu [accept dashavatara, anti prompt on “Kalki,” “Narasimha” or “Krishna”]

tossups.question: One of this author’s works features a man who travels to the Bashkirs and is eventually buried in a grave six feet long, thus answering the title question. In addition to “How Much Land Does a Man Need?”, this author wrote a story about Pozdnyshev, who confesses to killing his wife after she meets with the violinist Troukhatchevsky to play the title piece. In another work, this author of (*) The Kreutzer Sonata depicted a woman who throws herself under a train after an affair with Count Vronsky. He also wrote a novel that features Pierre Bezukhov, set during the Napoleonic invasion of Russia. For ten points, name this author of Anna Karenina and War and Peace.
tossups.answer: Leo Tolstoy [accept Count Lev Nikolyevich Tolstoy]

tossups.question: Two answers required. The Nazi John Rabe created a safe zone to protect civilians in one of these countries from the other’s army during a conflict that began after the Marco Polo Bridge incident. One of these countries justified an invasion of the other with the fabricated Mukden incident. Two officers of one of these two countries apocryphally raced to kill 100 residents of the other during its occupation of (*) Nanjing. An earlier war between these two countries saw the failure of the Qing Dynasty’s Self-Strengthening Movement contrasted with the successful Meiji Restoration. For ten points, name these countries, led from Beijing and Tokyo.
tossups.answer: People’s Republic of China and Japan [accept the Great Qing Dynasty or Zhongguo for China, Empire of Japan, Nippon, or Nihon for Japan]
tossups.answer_formatted: People’s Republic of China and Japan [accept the Great Qing Dynasty or Zhongguo for China, Empire of Japan, Nippon, or Nihon for Japan]
acceptable: People’s Republic of China and Japan
Zhongguo for China, Empire of Japan, Nippon,

tossups.question: This show featured Vanessa Vanjie Mateo, whose exit from it sparked the "Miss Vanjie" meme. One participant in this show, Jasmine Masters, coined the VSCO [visco] girl mantra "and I oop.” An episode of this show that appears every season is called Snatch Game and features celebrity impersonations. Participants in this show who place in the “bottom 2” are either told (*) "Shantay, you stay" or to "sashay away" after  lipsyncing for their lives. For ten points, name this reality show in which a group of drag queens compete for the title of America's Next Drag Superstar, hosted by RuPaul.
tossups.answer: RuPaul's Drag Race [accept RPDR, do not accept or prompt on RuPaul’s Drag Race: All Stars]
tossups.answer_formatted: RuPaul's Drag Race [accept RPDR, do not or or prompt on RuPaul’s Drag Race: All Stars]
acceptable: or prompt on RuPaul’s Drag Race: All Stars

tossups.question: Procedures on a buffy coat can help detect motile organisms in this substance. Observing a whip-like structure in one test of a substance can reveal the possibility of a parasite responsible for African sleeping sickness. The loss of this substance is prevented by a process involving von Willebrand factor and vitamin K. That disease involves the invasion of a barrier named for this substance and the (*) brain that prevents solutes from crossing into extracellular fluid of the nervous system. This fluid’s “types” are classified into A, B, and O groups. For ten points, name this fluid responsible for the circulation of nutrients and oxygen throughout the human body.
tossups.answer: blood

tossups.question: A large sculpture featuring this figure in blue and green is seated near Morecambe Bay in England. Many rounded Paleolithic figurines are named after this figure, including one found at Willendorf. Antonio Canova sculpted this figure holding an apple in their hand as she is reclining and “Victorious”, using (*) Pauline Borghese as the model. A sculpture of this figure previously attributed to Praxiteles was found on a Greek island and is now housed in the Louvre. For ten points, name this goddess who is armless in a sculpted titled [this goddess] de Milo.
tossups.answer: Venus [accept Aphrodite; accept Venus of Willendorf, accept Paolina Borghese as Venus Victrix, accept Venus de Milo]
tossups.answer_formatted: Venus [accept Aphrodite; accept Venus of Willendorf, or Paolina Borghese as Venus Victrix, or Venus de Milo]

tossups.question: The Solow economic growth model is based on the dynamics of this concept. Thomas Picketty claimed that inequality arises when income from this concept outweighs long term economic growth in a book describing it in the Twenty-first Century. A book titled for this concept that presents a “labor theory of value” warns that exploited labor can become (*) “commodity fetishism,” and was later redacted by Friedrich Engels after the death of its author. Gary Becker popularized the “human” type of this concept. For ten points, name this factor of production, contrasted with land and labor, which titles a Karl Marx work.
tossups.answer: capital [accept Das Kapital]

tossups.question: John Tenniel satirized one of this leader’s decisions in the cartoon “Dropping the Pilot.” This ruler harmed their country’s relations with the UK after an interview with the Daily Telegraph in which this ruler accused the English people of being “mad as March hares.” In an 1897 speech, this leader’s foreign minister (*) Bernhard von Bülow outlined how this ruler’s nation wanted its “place in the sun.” The “New Course” policy was pursued by Leo von Caprivi after this ruler dismissed Otto von Bismarck. Germany entered World War I under, for ten points, what last German emperor?
tossups.answer: Kaiser Wilhelm II [accept William II; prompt on Wilhelm]

tossups.question: An author from this country used “Rotten English” to write his novel Sozaboy. In a play from this country, four women perform the “Dance of the Lost Traveller” where they imitate a man with a camera. Ken Saro-Wiwa is from this country, which is the setting of a play where Baroka and Lakunle fight for Sidi’s affections and another play where (*) Simon Pilkings arrests Elesin Oba to prevent him from committing ritual suicide. The writer of the plays The Lion and the Jewel and The Death and the King’s Horseman is from this country. For ten points, name this nation where the plays of the Yoruban Wole Soyinka were performed in Lagos.
tossups.answer: Federal Republic of Nigeria

tossups.question: It’s not a conveyer belt, but in order to reduce wear by friction over these objects, a half turn is made to shape a loop into a Mobius strip. In a simple setup with one of these objects and two masses, the net acceleration of each mass is proportional to the ratio between the difference of the masses over the sum of the masses. Two masses are connected by string across one of these objects in an (*) Atwood machine. The mechanical advantage of these objects, which compose a tackle system, is proportional to the number of supporting segments. For ten points, name these simple machines consisting of string around a wheel.
tossups.answer: pulley [anti-prompt on Atwood machine before it is mentioned]
tossups.answer_formatted: pulley [anti-prompt on Atwood machine before it is mentioned]

tossups.question: Robert Geldof and Midge Ure organized the Live Aid concert to combat a mid-1980s famine in this country. After losing the Battle of Magdala, this country’s emperor Tewodros II committed suicide in 1868. The Zagwe and Solomonid dynasties ruled this country until the rise of the communist Derg regime in 1974. Under (*) Menelik II, this country defeated an invading force at the Battle of Adwa in 1896, and in 1936, Haile Selassie denounced Italy’s aggression towards this country at the League of Nations. Eritrea seceded from, for ten points, what country with capital Addis Ababa?
tossups.answer: Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia [accept Ethiopian Empire, prompt on Abyssinia]
tossups.answer_formatted: Federal Democratic Republic of Ethiopia [accept Ethiopian Empire, prompt on Abyssinia]

bonuses.leadin: This substance combines with fire within Ginnungagap in a Norse creation myth. For ten points each:
answers: ice [accept snow, frost, or reasonable equivalents]
Poetic Edda [prompt on Edda, do not accept or prompt on “Prose Edda”]
parts: Name this substance for which the giant Ymir is named. In an event that precedes Ragnarok, the world is covered in this substance for three straight seasons with no intervening summer.

Vafthrudnir tells Odin that Lif and Lifthrasir will survive the aforementioned Fimbulwinter by hiding in Hoddmímis Holt, which is often interpreted to be this location. Hoddmimis may be cognate to Mimir, whose well is contained in this location.
The Vathrudnismal is the third poem in this collection, which also includes the Voluspa and the Lokasenna.
answers_formatted: Poetic Edda [prompt on Edda, do not accept or prompt on “Prose Edda”]

bonuses.leadin: After being defeated during a battle in this location, Huldrych Zwingli was killed by Hans Jauch’s Catholic forces. For ten points each:
answers: Kappel am Albis [accept Wars of Kappel]
parts: Name this municipality that names a pair of wars in 1529 and 1531 between Catholic and Protestant forces.
Zwingli is generally credited with initiating the Protestant Revolution in this country during the “Affair of the Sausages.” John Calvin was another proponent of Protestantism in this country.
During the Marburg Colloquy, Zwingli debated with this other Protestant leader. This man’s publication of his Ninety-five Theses started the Protestant Reformation

bonuses.leadin: This character’s home city was sacked by Achilles, and all her brothers were killed. For ten points each:
parts: Name this character. Her son Astyanax and husband Hector were both killed during the Trojan War, and in some stories, she becomes a concubine of Neoptolemus, Achilles’ son.

In an epic about the founding of Rome, this protagonist visits Andromache, who has married Helenus and become Queen of Epirus. Later in that work, which begins “I sing of arms and the man,” this character visits the Cumaean Sibyl, who tells him he must acquire a golden bough before visiting his father Anchises in the underworld.

This Greek playwright wrote about Andromache in both The Trojan Women and his play Andromache. Another of his plays ends when the title character exits in a chariot pulled by dragons, that play is Medea.

bonuses.leadin: The Lorentz-Lorenz equation relates this quantity for a substance to its polarizability. For ten points each:
answers: index of refraction [or refractive index or IOR; prompt on n; do not accept or prompt on “refraction”]
negative [accept negative-index metamaterial or left-handed metamaterial; accept logical equivalents such as less than zero; prompt on NIM]
parts: Name this optical quantity that is equal to 1 for a vacuum. Values of this dimensionless quantity for two materials are related to one another in Snell’s law.

When the difference in index of refraction for two media is high, the “total internal” form of this phenomenon is likely to occur. This phenomenon more commonly occurs when light bounces off of a mirror.
In 1967, Victor Veselago studied metamaterials whose indices of refraction have this property. Indexes of refraction with this property cause reverse propagation of electromagnetic waves.
answers_formatted: index of refraction [or refractive index or IOR; prompt on n; do not accept or prompt on "“refraction”"]
negative [accept negative-index metamaterial or left-handed metamaterial; accept logical equivalents such as less than zero; prompt on NIM]
acceptable: logical equivalents such as less than zero

bonuses.leadin: The scandalous subjects depicted in one large painting by this artist caused them to stand trial in front of the Inquisition. For ten points each:
parts: Name this Italian Renaissance artist who depicted dogs, drunken revelers, and a large meal in The Feast in the House of Levi.
In The Supper at Emmaus, Caravaggio unusually depicted this figure without a beard having a meal of poultry and fruit. This figure also sits at the center of The Feast in the House of Levi.
The Feast in the House of Levi is located in the Gallerie dell'Accademia in this city which also holds Tintoretto’s Last Supper. The artist Canaletto painted many of this city’s canals.

bonuses.leadin: The Red River Delta in this country served as a hotbed for revolutionary activity. For ten points each:
answers: Socialist Republic of Vietnam [accept Cộng hòa xã hội chủ nghĩa Việt Nam]
Trưng Sisters [accept Hai Bà Trưng or Two Ladies Trưng, accept Trưng Trắc AND Trưng Nhị]
parts: Name this Southeast Asian country that led the Yue Revolt and fought the Battle of Bach Dang River. It was unified by the Communist Party in 1976 with capital at Hanoi.

These two Vietnamese warriors were notable for riding elephants and commanding a female army against China. Legendarily, when these figures threw themselves into a river to escape an oncoming army, they were turned into statues.
The Trưng Sisters rebelled against this Chinese dynasty. Liu Bang founded this dynasty, which shares its name with China’s largest ethnic group.
answers_formatted: Socialist Republic of Vietnam [accept Cộng hòa xã hội chủ nghĩa Việt Nam]
Trưng Sisters [accept Hai Bà Trưng or Two Ladies Trưng, or Trưng Trắc AND Trưng Nhị]
acceptable: Cộng hòa xã hội chủ nghĩa Việt Nam

bonuses.leadin: Gwendolyn Brooks’ book of poetry Annie Allen takes place in the Bronzeville Neighborhood of this city. For ten points each:
parts: Name this city which is called a “slacker of wheat” and “hog butcher of the world” in one poem. That Carl Sandburg poem titled for this city describes it as a “City of the Big Shoulders”.
This Lorraine Hansberry play set in Chicago depicts the Younger family’s attempts to move into the predominantly white Clybourne Park neighborhood.

This Pulitzer Prize-winning American playwright wrote the 2018 novel Chicago. This playwright used tons of vulgar language in a play in which real estate agents like Shelly Levene battle over leads, Glengarry Glen Ross.

bonuses.leadin: This player was dubbed “Pandemic P” in reference to his putrid play for some of the 2020 NBA Playoffs. For ten points each:
parts: Name this forward and six-time NBA All-Star. He was traded to his current team from the Thunder for a package including Shai Gilgeous-Alexander and five first-round picks.

On his team, George forms a star duo with this other forward. As a member of the Spurs, he won the 2014 Finals MVP for his defense on Lebron James and he recently won the 2019 Finals MVP while leading the Raptors to their first-ever title.
Paul George and Kawhi Leonard play for the Clippers, an NBA team based in this city. The Clippers currently share the Staples Center in this city with the Lakers.

bonuses.leadin: Plasmodesmata are small channels found between this structure for two plant cells. For ten points each:
parts: Name this structural component of cells that maintains rigidity and surrounds the cell membrane. In plants, this structure is primarily made of cellulose.

The cell walls of bacteria contain this polymer that consists of alternating beta 1,4 glycosidic linkages between NAG and NAM. Penicillin inhibits enzymes that cause the cross-linking of this polymer.
Bacterial cell walls that are high in peptidoglycan produce a positive result in this technique. Bacteria that produce a negative result in this technique retain the compound safranin.

bonuses.leadin: This author allegorized themselves as Anne Dubreuilh in her novel The Mandarins. For ten points each:
parts: Name this philosopher. This author described how man is considered the default, while women are considered the other, in a work that was published in Le temps modernes.

In The Ethics of Ambiguity, Beauvoir adhered to this philosophical viewpoint, which argues that all people are fundamentally free. Other adherents of this theory include Albert Camus, and de Beauvoir’s partner Jean-Paul Sartre.

This work by de Beauvoir details the treatment of women throughout history, and also discusses the differences in how boys and girls are raised. In this work, Beauvoir declares that “one is not born, but rather becomes, a woman.”

bonuses.leadin: The “divide and conquer” paradigm is often employed when creating these entities. For ten points each:
parts: Name these step-by-step methods of performing computer tasks. They generally consist of instructions that transform a given input into an output.

The A* [A-star] algorithm is a generalization of this algorithm that can be used if a lower bound to the target “distance” is available. This algorithm finds the shortest path between nodes and is named for a Dutch computer scientist.
Dijkstra's algorithm operates on this type of construct. This abstract data type consists of vertices connected by edges and is often studied in discrete mathematics.

bonuses.leadin: This speech claims that “the attorney in a country town is as much a businessman as the corporation counsel in a great metropolis.” For ten points each:
parts: Name this speech delivered at the 1896 Democratic National Convention that warns business interests not to “press down upon the brow of labor this crown of thorns.”

This politician, the Democratic and Populist nominee in 1896, delivered the Cross of Gold speech. This politician later argued an anti-evolution stance against Clarence Darrow in the Scopes Monkey Trial.

In 1990, Hugh Rockoff argued that this 1900 novel was an allegory for the 1896 election and the disputes over bimetallism. Quentin Taylor proposed that Bryan was represented by this novel’s character of the Cowardly Lion.

bonuses.leadin: This man was injured while fighting in the Anglo-Afghan Wars. For ten points each:
parts: Name this physician, the narrator of stories like The Adventure of Silver Blaze and The Sign of the Four.

Watson narrates most of the stories about this fictional detective. This detective, who was created by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle, solves mysteries in The Hound of the Baskervilles and A Study in Scarlet.

In Conan Doyle’s story, The Final Problem, Holmes and his nemesis Moriarty fight at this scenic location in Switzerland. Though both die, Conan Doyle later resurrected Holmes for The Adventure of the Empty House.

bonuses.leadin: For ten points each, answer the following about the composer Luigi Boccherini:
parts: Boccherini played this instrument, for which he composed a concerto in B-flat major. An Edward Elgar concerto for this instrument was recorded by Jacqueline du Pré.
Boccherini is best remembered for one of these dance movements from his String Quintet in E. These dances in ¾ [three four] time were often paired with a trio in the third movement of symphonies.
Boccherini worked for several years at this city’s Burgtheater. Haydn, Mozart, and Beethoven were part of a school named for this capital of Austria during the Classical period.

bonuses.leadin: War is hell, and German authors knew it. For ten points each, name the following about German literature about World War I:
answers: All Quiet on the Western Front
billiards [accept Billiards at Half-Past Nine, accept pool]
parts: Paul Baumer is inspired by the schoolteacher Kantorek to enlist in the German army in this Erich Maria Remarque novel.
Hans Castorp enlists in the military to fight in World War I after leaving a Swiss sanatorium at the end of The Magic Mountain, a novel by this author of Buddenbrooks.

Heinrich Böll wrote a novel about the Faehmel family coping with the impacts of both world wars in a novel titled for this activity “at Half-Past Nine.” In The Cherry Orchard, Gayev is addicted to this game.
acceptable: All Quiet on the Western Front

bonuses.leadin: Some of the smallest counties in the United States have great geographic importance. For ten points each:
answers: Manhattan [or the County of New York]
parts: The second-smallest county in the US is located in this borough of New York City. Attractions in this borough include the Empire State Building and Times Square.
The smallest county in the US is Kalawao County, a former leper colony on this Hawaiian island. This island, east of Oahu, contains the longest fringing coral reef in the United States.

Nantucket County, the seventh-smallest county, is east of this popular New England summer destination. This island, which is located south of Cape Cod, is connected to mainland Massachusetts by a ferry departing from Woods Hole.

bonuses.leadin: For ten points each, answer the following about Dido and her appearances in opera:
answers: [10] Perhaps the most famous opera about Dido is this English composer’s Dido and Aeneas, which includes the aria “Dido’s Lament.” This composer’s works are catalogued using Z numbers. ANSWER: Henry Purcell
parts: Perhaps the most famous opera about Dido is this English composer’s Dido and Aeneas, which includes the aria “Dido’s Lament.” This composer’s works are catalogued using Z numbers.
The libretto “Didone abbandonata” [dee-DOH-nay ah-BAHN-doh-nah-tah] was used by multiple composers from this modern day country, including Leonardo Vinci, Giuseppe Sarti, and Niccolo Piccinni.

Dido also features in Les Troyens, a grand opera by this French composer. This composer depicted a man who turns to opium after his love is unrequited in a programmatic work subtitled “Episode in the Life of an Artist,” the Symphonie Fantastique.

bonuses.leadin: Molecules that exhibit the geometric form of this property are labelled as either cis or trans. For ten points each:
parts: Identify this property of compounds that can have identical chemical formulas but different chemical structures. Branched alkanes such as neobutane exhibit the structural form of this property.
Molecules with this property exhibit stereoisomerism because they are not superimposable on their mirror images. This property is denoted using the letters R and S.

This type of mixture contains equal parts of left and right handed enantiomers of a chiral molecule. The first of these optically inactive mixtures was synthesized by Louis Pasteur with tartaric acid.

bonuses.leadin: This politician was exiled from his home city of Athens and defected to Persia, only to return four years later after a coup. For ten points each:
parts: Name this charismatic orator and general, who was exiled from their home city after being accused of destroying religious statues the night before a military expedition.
Alcibiades went to this city after being exiled from Athens. This Peloponnesian city with a warlike reputation fought against Athens during the Peloponnesian War.

Alcibiades was the main proponent of an Athenian conquest of this island, though he was exiled before the expedition took place. The expedition ended disastrously when Athenian armies were routed at Syracuse.

bonuses.leadin: Extinguishing an oil lamp has been analogized to this concept. For ten points each:
parts: Name this Buddhist term for the release from samsara, or the cycle of rebirth. Siddhartha Gautama reached this enlightened state under a Bodhi tree.

The Buddhist concept of upaya is illustrated through a parable where a father promises a toy cart to his child to escape a burning house in a Mahayana sutra named after one of these objects called a lotus.
These cryptic and paradoxical statements are used to illustrate the principles of Zen Buddhism. Many of them are compiled in works such as Blue Cliff Record and The Gateless Gate.
